Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: IA: F: Structural Anonymization Techniques for Large, Labeled, and Dynamic Social Graphs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this work is to provide big data owners with tools to safely share their social networks data with the research community. The specific type of big data is large online social graphs that evolve over time due to two different dynamic processes: one is the natural evolution of the graph with edge and node removal and insertion; the other is a dynamic process that changes the state of the vertices of the network. Real, longitudinal social graphs datasets are fundamental to understanding a variety of phenomena, such as epidemics, adoption of behavior, crowd management and political uprisings. However, publishing real data is significantly hampered by serious privacy risks: even when humans' identities are removed, studies have proven repeatedly that de-anonymization is doable with high success rate. This project aims to investigate and compare structural anonymization techniques that rely on generating graphs with given characteristics of the original, real graph. The results of this study alleviate the privacy and security risks related to graph sharing and contribute to a faster understanding of natural and social phenomena on real graphs by facilitating real graph sharing for better, faster, more impactful research. The project also contributes to the understanding of dynamic processes on social graphs; involves graduate and undergraduate students in interdisciplinary research; shares resulting code on github; enhances curriculum via collaborative teaching targeted at Sociology and Computer Science students; and disseminates resulting knowledge to audiences ranging from middleschool to graduate students via presentation, publications, and summer schools.

The project aims to approach graph anonymization via two techniques for graph generation: dK-series techniques, introduced in the context of internet network generation, and Exponential Random Graph Model-based approaches (ERGM), which are the state of the art in modeling social networks in Sociology. For each approach, the project first investigates its effectiveness on anonymizing static social networks sampled from representative datasets (some available, others collected as part of this effort). Second, it adapts the dK series and ERGM techniques to dynamic social networks based on empirical characterizations of the evolution of social relations. Third, the empirically-described dynamic processes are added on top of the static and dynamic networks from the previous steps. And finally, the research focuses on scaling up the computational techniques to be able to anonymize social (thus, sparse) graphs in the order of millions of nodes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Real social graphs datasets are fundamental to understanding a variety of phenomena, such as epidemics, adoption of behavior, crowd management and political uprisings. At the same time, many such datasets capturing computer-mediated social interactions are recorded nowadays by individual researchers or by organizations. However, while the need for real social graphs and the supply of such datasets are well established, the flow of data from data owners to researchers is significantly hampered by serious privacy risks: even when humans’ identities are removed, studies have proven repeatedly that de-anonymization is doable with high success rate. Such de-anonymization techniques reconstruct user identities using third-party public data and the graph structure of the naively anonymized social network: specifically, the information about one’s social ties, even without the particularities of the individual nodes, is sufficient to re-identify individuals. The risks are so serious that companies hesitate to share datasets in an attempt to contain user privacy breaches.

The approach to deal with these risks is to anonymize social graphs by modifying the graph structure enough as to decouple the particular node identity from its social ties yet preserving the graph characteristics in aggregate. Various solutions have been proposed, some based on rewiring the original graph structure, others based on clustering, and others based on generating graphs from a graph signature. For all structural graph anonymization techniques, however, the challenge is the tension between providing privacy in the altered graph structure and preserving the accuracy of the structural characteristics of the original graph in the altered graph, which is what matters for their utility for research. This project addressed the problem of the anonymity of social network datasets where nodes have binary attributes that describes a dynamic, diffusion process (such as contaminated or not).

Some of our main research contributions are the following: First, we developed a theoretical and software framework for empirically exploring the tradeoffs between utility and anonimity for network datasets. This is particularly useful for data providers and data scientists in selecting the right compromises for utility, that is, which network characteristics to lose in the anonymized version in order to achieve the desired level of privacy for the nodes in the network.

Second, we showed that binary node attributes increase the vulnerability of a network dataset to de-anonymization attacks but to what degree is a matter of attribute distribution. This observation is useful to data providers as it shows that the position of the node attributes in the network does not add significant vulnerability in deanonymization attacks. Consequently, releasing datasets that represent isolated snapshots of a diffusion process, for example, does not increase the risks of node identification compared to releasing the network structure with randomly assigned attribute values.

Third, we studied various network dynamics processes and observed new behaviors. For example, previous work showed that a critical mass of a persistent minority can influence the behavior of a network in a topology closer to one resulted from chance. Our work shows that real-world social networks with polarized communities are highly resistant to change independent of the size of the persistent minority. It turns out that more relevant that size is the position of the nodes in the persistent minority and their contacts with the opposite community.

And finally, we investigated approaches to graph generation using deep learning technologies as ways to anonymize network datasets that record contagion processes. We showed empirically that the specific characteristics of social media and social network datasets pose particular challenges to such graph learning solutions, which suggests new research directions in deep learning.

This research contributed to the interdisciplinary education in research of two undergraduate students and seven graduate students from both Computer Science and Sociology. Five MS theses and PhD dissertations have been completed so far on research related to this project. In addition, topics related to this research have been included in courses offered to computer science and engineering students at both graduate and undergraduate levels.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2020
Modified by: Adriana Iamnitchi

At the same time, many such datasets capturing computer-mediated social interactions are recorded nowadays by individual researchers or by organizations. However, while the need for real social graphs and the supply of such datasets are well established, the flow of data from data owners to researchers is significantly hampered by serious privacy risks: even when humans’ identities are removed, studies have proven repeatedly that de-anonymization is doable with high success rate. Such de-anonymization techniques reconstruct user identities using third-party public data and the graph structure of the naively anonymized social network: specifically, the information about one’s social ties, even without the particularities of the individual nodes, is sufficient to re-identify individuals. The risks are so serious that companies hesitate to share datasets in an attempt to contain user privacy breaches.
